head.title: To Search Your Roots, A Guide From the County

hedline.hl1: To Search Your Roots, A Guide From the County

abstract.p: Westchester County Archives publishes guide that lists resources available to public for genealogical research; it includes sources like early telephone books that list residents' occupations as well as their addresses and phone numbers (S)

block.p: The Westchester County Archives has published a guide that lists resources available to the public for genealogical research. It includes sources like early telephone books that list residents' occupations as well their addresses and phone numbers; local newspapers including marriage and death notices, and reports from local school districts dating back to 1828 with student names and faculty lists.

Also available are records created during the 1930's by the Works Progress Administration on veterans of wars from 1775 to 1918 who are buried in Westchester. In addition, there are resources detailing names, ages and living conditions in Westchester's orphanages, as well as church records, incorporation papers, court records, voter enrollments and maps.

The Westchester County Archives has published a guide that lists resources available to the public for genealogical research. It includes sources like early telephone books that list residents' occupations as well their addresses and phone numbers; local newspapers including marriage and death notices, and reports from local school districts dating back to 1828 with student names and faculty lists.

Also available are records created during the 1930's by the Works Progress Administration on veterans of wars from 1775 to 1918 who are buried in Westchester. In addition, there are resources detailing names, ages and living conditions in Westchester's orphanages, as well as church records, incorporation papers, court records, voter enrollments and maps.
The guide has been distributed to local municipal clerks, public libraries, historical societies, the Westchester Genealogical Society and various county and state offices.
Copies are available by calling (914)231-1500 or visit the Westchester County Archives during public hours, on Tuesday or Wednesday from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m., at 2199 Saw Mill River Road in Elmsford.
